Turnbull promises faster Kiwi deportation appeals Prime minister Malcolm Turnbull promises to expedite the appeals process for New Zealanders facing deportation from Australia. Courtesy ABC News 24.
PT1M2S 620 349 Autoplay On Off Video feedback Video settings Malcolm Turnbull has sought to calm New Zealand's anger over the increasing number of Kiwis being locked up in Australia's immigration detention centres by pledging to fast-track their appeals.
On his first overseas trip since seizing the prime ministership last month, Mr Turnbull also moved to address a long-running trans-Tasman feud over benefits and entitlements by agreeing to give some New Zealanders access to Australia's student loans scheme.
While Mr Turnbull spent fewer than 24 hours on the ground in Auckland, he spent more than five hours talking with his New Zealand counterpart, John Key, first over dinner at an exclusive downtown restaurant and then in their official meeting.
Malcolm and Lucy Turnbull with John Key and his wife Bronagh before going to dinner in Auckland. Photo: David Foote
The men, who have followed remarkably similar career trajectories and share many of the same beliefs, were effusive in their praise for each other – despite the detention and deportation issue that has angered many Kiwis.
Advertisement Hundreds of New Zealanders are currently being held in Australian detention centres, including 40 on Christmas Island, and it's believed up to 1000 are in the pipeline for deportation – some of whom have lived in Australia most of their lives and have committed only minor crimes. The growing numbers come as a result of new immigration laws under which people can have their visas cancelled if they've been cumulatively sentenced to 12 months or more in prison.
Mr Turnbull said Mr Key was very direct with his concerns.
Illustration: Matt Golding.
"We do understand the problem; we do understand how it's perceived in New Zealand and John has been very forthright in our discussions," he said.
He has asked Immigration Minister Peter Dutton to devote "considerable extra resources" to get the appeals going faster but says he is not considering any changes to give New Zealanders special treatment.
The Prime Minister also announced his government will introduce legislation into Parliament next week that will make around 2600 New Zealanders eligible for student loans to help them pay for tuition at Australian universities or TAFE.
The changes will apply to Special Category Visa holders who came to Australia as dependent children and have lived here for at least 10 years. If the bill passes this year as planned the changes will come into effect on January 1, 2016.
"This bill represents important opportunities for New Zealanders who have long called Australia home, and provides fairness given Australians on certain visa categories have long had access to New Zealand's student loan scheme," Mr Turnbull said.
Indeed, Australians in New Zealand are able to access a range of entitlements that Kiwis in Australia can't, including unemployment benefits.
New Zealand Prime Minister John Key welcomed the announcement but made it clear more needed to be done.
"I just hope over time that we can make some more progress," he said. "We are lifters in the Australian economy; we are not leaners. We don't go to Australia looking for a free lunch."
Mr Turnbull has pledged to do all he can to further improve Australia's relationship with New Zealand, describing it as a "love affair" that needs work.
Mr Key has been in power for seven years, increasing his majority at every election, while Australia has churned through five prime ministers in as many years. But he believes Mr Turnbull will be the one to break the cycle.
"I think you'll not only be a fine prime minister of Australia, you'll be a long-term leader of Australia," he said.
